message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: AI Agents and Agentic Systems: A Multi-Expert Analysis
Paper Abstract: The emergence of AI agents and agentic systems represents a significant milestone in artificial intelligence, enabling autonomous systems to operate, learn, and collaborate in complex environments with minimal human intervention. This paper, drawing on multi-expert perspectives, examines the potential of AI agents and agentic systems to reshape industries by decentralizing decision-making, redefining organizational structures, and enhancing cross-functional collaboration. Specific applications include healthcare systems capable of creating adaptive treatment plans, supply chain agents that predict and address disruptions in real-time, and business process automation that reallocates tasks from humans to AI, improving efficiency and innovation. However, the integration of these systems raises critical challenges, including issues of attribution and shared accountability in decision-making, compatibility with legacy systems, and addressing biases in AI-driven processes. The paper concludes that while agentic systems hold immense promise, robust governance frameworks, cross-industry collaboration, and interdisciplinary research into ethical design are essential. Future research should explore adaptive workforce reskilling strategies, transparent accountability mechanisms, and energy-efficient deployment models to ensure ethical and scalable implementation.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

## Machine Learning Overview

I found comprehensive information about machine learning. Here are the key points:

### Definition
Machine learning (ML) is a field of study in artificial intelligence concerned with the development and study of statistical algorithms that can learn from data and generalise to unseen data, and thus perform tasks without explicit instructions.

### Learning Paradigms
Machine learning is commonly separated into three main learning paradigms: supervised learning, unsupervised learning and reinforcement learning.

### Applications
ML finds application in many fields, including natural language processing, computer vision, speech recognition, email filtering, agriculture, and medicine.

### Historical Background
The term machine learning was coined in 1959 by Arthur Samuel, an IBM employee and pioneer in the field of computer gaming and artificial intelligence.(no content)The earliest machine learning program was introduced in the 1950s when Arthur Samuel invented a computer program that calculated the winning chance in checkers for each side.

### Neural Networks
In machine learning, a neural network (NN), also called artificial neural network (ANN), is a computational model inspired by the structure and functions of biological neural networks. A neural network consists of connected units or nodes called artificial neurons, which loosely model the neurons in the brain.

Here are the search results for "autonomous systems":

The term "autonomous systems" can refer to several different concepts depending on the context:

## Internet and Networking
An autonomous system (AS) is a collection of connected Internet Protocol (IP) routing prefixes under the control of one or more network operators on behalf of a single administrative entity or domain, that presents a common and clearly defined routing policy to the Internet.

## Robotics and AI
An autonomous agent is an artificial intelligence (AI) system that can perform complex tasks independently.(no content)An autonomous agent is a system situated within and a part of an environment that senses that environment and acts on it, over time, in pursuit of its own agenda and so as to effect what it senses in the future.(no content)The most advanced systems now fuse information from various sensors for both localization (position) and navigation, and systems such as Motivity can rely on different sensors in different areas and can re-map a building autonomously.

## Decentralized Systems
An autonomous decentralized system (or ADS) is a decentralized system composed of modules or components that are designed to operate independently but are capable of interacting with each other to meet the overall goal of the system.

## Mathematics
In mathematics, an autonomous system or autonomous differential equation is a system of ordinary differential equations which does not explicitly depend on the independent variable.

## Business Process Automation

Based on the search results, here's an overview of business process automation:

### Definition
Business process automation (BPA) is the technology-enabled automation of complex business processes.(no content)It can help to streamline a business for simplicity, achieve digital transformation, increase service quality, improve service delivery or contain costs.

### Components and Implementation
BPA consists of integrating applications, restructuring labor resources and using software applications throughout the organization.(no content)BPAs can be implemented in a number of business areas including marketing, sales and workflow.

### Approaches to BPA
Traditional business process automation entails developing BPA software in a programming language for integrating relevant applications in the digital ecosystem to execute a given process; robotic process automation uses software robots to emulate human-computer interaction for executing a combination of processes, activities, transactions, and tasks in one or more unrelated software systems.

Additionally, hyperautomation combines business process automation, artificial intelligence (AI), and machine learning (ML) to discover, validate, and execute organizational processes automatically with no or minimal human intervention.

### Benefits
Robotic process automation is designed to streamline workflows by delegating repetitive tasks to software agents, allowing human workers to focus on more complex and strategic activities.

## Business Process Automation

Based on the search results, here's an overview of business process automation:

### Definition
Business process automation (BPA) is the technology-enabled automation of complex business processes.(no content)It can help to streamline a business for simplicity, achieve digital transformation, increase service quality, improve service delivery or contain costs.

### Components and Implementation
BPA consists of integrating applications, restructuring labor resources and using software applications throughout the organization.(no content)BPAs can be implemented in a number of business areas including marketing, sales and workflow.

### Approaches to BPA
Traditional business process automation entails developing BPA software in a programming language for integrating relevant applications in the digital ecosystem to execute a given process; robotic process automation uses software robots to emulate human-computer interaction for executing a combination of processes, activities, transactions, and tasks in one or more unrelated software systems.

Additionally, hyperautomation combines business process automation, artificial intelligence (AI), and machine learning (ML) to discover, validate, and execute organizational processes automatically with no or minimal human intervention.

### Benefits
Robotic process automation is designed to streamline workflows by delegating repetitive tasks to software agents, allowing human workers to focus on more complex and strategic activities.

Web search results for query: "AI agents artificial intelligence"

Links: [{"title":"Intelligent agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligent_agent"},{"title":"AI agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agentic_AI"},{"title":"Software agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_agent"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Autonomous agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_agent"},{"title":"List of artificial intelligence projects - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_artificial_intelligence_projects"},{"title":"Manus (AI agent) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manus_(AI_agent)"},{"title":"AI-assisted software development - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AI-assisted_software_development"},{"title":"Deliberative agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deliberative_agent"},{"title":"Artificial general intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_general_intelligence"}]

## Search Results for "AI agents artificial intelligence"

Here's what I found about AI agents and artificial intelligence:

### What are AI Agents?

In artificial intelligence, an intelligent agent is an entity that perceives its environment, takes actions autonomously to achieve goals, and may improve its performance through machine learning or by acquiring knowledge.(no content)AI textbooks define artificial intelligence as the "study and design of intelligent agents," emphasizing that goal-directed behavior is central to intelligence.

### Types and Characteristics

In the context of generative artificial intelligence, AI agents (also referred to as compound AI systems or agentic AI) are a class of intelligent agents distinguished by their ability to operate autonomously in complex environments.(no content)Intelligent agents can range from simple to highly complex. A basic thermostat or control system is considered an intelligent agent, as is a human being, or any other system that meets the same criteria—such as a firm, a state, or a biome.

### Applications

A common application of AI agents is the automation of tasks—for example, booking travel plans based on a user's prompted request.(no content)Further examples of agents released since 2025 include OpenAI Operator, ChatGPT Deep Research, Manus, Quark (based on Qwen), AutoGLM Rumination, and Coze (by ByteDance).

### Development Frameworks

Frameworks for building AI agents include LangChain, as well as tools such as CAMEL, Microsoft AutoGen, and OpenAI Swarm.

Web search results for query: "healthcare AI"

Links: [{"title":"Artificial intelligence in healthcare - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_in_healthcare"},{"title":"Ethics of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethics_of_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Edwin Mercado - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edwin_Mercado"},{"title":"Genesis Mission - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genesis_Mission"},{"title":"MediSafe controversy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MediSafe_controversy"},{"title":"AI therapist - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AI_therapist"},{"title":"Kyunghyun Cho - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kyunghyun_Cho"},{"title":"Human-AI interaction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human-AI_interaction"},{"title":"Timi Olagunju - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timi_Olagunju"},{"title":"AI-generated content in American politics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AI-generated_content_in_American_politics"}]

Here's an overview of healthcare AI based on the search results:

## What is Healthcare AI?

Artificial intelligence in healthcare is the application of artificial intelligence (AI) to analyze and understand complex medical and healthcare data.(no content)In some cases, it can exceed or augment human capabilities by providing better or faster ways to diagnose, treat, or prevent disease.

## Key Applications

**Diagnosis and Clinical Support**
AI can assist clinicians with its data processing capabilities to save time and improve accuracy, and through machine learning, artificial intelligence can be able to substantially aid doctors in patient diagnosis through the analysis of mass electronic health records (EHRs).(no content)AI can help early prediction, for example, of Alzheimer's disease and dementias, by looking through large numbers of similar cases and possible treatments.

**Electronic Health Records**
Around 80% of medical practices use EHR, and some anticipate the use of artificial intelligence to interpret the records and provide new information to physicians.

**Mental Health Support**
AI therapists are artificial intelligence systems designed to provide mental health support through chatbots or virtual assistants, and often include elements of structured therapies such as cognitive behavioral therapy, mood tracking, or psychoeducation.

## Challenges and Concerns

New technologies such as AI are often met with resistance by healthcare leaders, leading to slow and erratic adoption. Additionally, in healthcare, the use of complex AI methods often results in models described as "black-boxes" due to the difficulty to understand how they work, and the decisions made by such models can be hard to interpret, as it is challenging to analyze how input data is transformed into output. This lack of transparency is a significant concern in fields like healthcare, where understanding the rationale behind decisions can be crucial for trust, ethical considerations, and compliance with regulatory standards.

Links: [{"title":"Reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Reinforcement learning from human feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning_from_human_feedback"},{"title":"Multi-agent reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Self-play (reinforcement learning technique) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-play_(reinforcement_learning_technique)"},{"title":"Model-free (reinforcement learning) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model-free_(reinforcement_learning)"},{"title":"Category:Reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Deep reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deep_reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Q-learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Q-learning"},{"title":"Self-supervised learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-supervised_learning"},{"title":"Imitation learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Imitation_learning"}]

Here are the search results for "reinforcement learning":

## Overview

Reinforcement learning (RL) is concerned with how an intelligent agent should take actions in a dynamic environment in order to maximize a reward signal.(no content)Reinforcement learning is one of the three basic machine learning paradigms, alongside supervised learning and unsupervised learning.

## Key Concepts

While supervised learning and unsupervised learning algorithms respectively attempt to discover patternsin labeled and unlabeled data, reinforcement learning involves training an agent through interactions with its environment.(no content)To learn to maximize rewards from these interactions, the agent makes decisions between trying new actions to learn more about the environment (exploration), or using current knowledge of the environment to take the best action (exploitation). The search for the optimal balance between these two strategies is known as the exploration–exploitation dilemma.

## Applications

Reinforcement learning has been applied successfully to various problems, including energy storage, robot control, photovoltaic generators, backgammon, checkers, Go (AlphaGo), and autonomous driving systems.(no content)Deep reinforcement learning has been used for a diverse set of applications including but not limited to robotics, video games, natural language processing, computer vision, education, transportation, finance and healthcare.

## Subfields and Techniques

Some specialized areas of reinforcement learning include:
- Multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) is a sub-field of reinforcement learning. It focuses on studying the behavior of multiple learning agents that coexist in a shared environment.
- Self-play is a technique for improving the performance of reinforcement learning agents.
- Reinforcement learning from human feedback (RLHF) is a technique to align an intelligent agent with human preferences.

Here are the search results for "reinforcement learning":

## Overview

Reinforcement learning (RL) is concerned with how an intelligent agent should take actions in a dynamic environment in order to maximize a reward signal.(no content)Reinforcement learning is one of the three basic machine learning paradigms, alongside supervised learning and unsupervised learning.

## Key Concepts

While supervised learning and unsupervised learning algorithms respectively attempt to discover patternsin labeled and unlabeled data, reinforcement learning involves training an agent through interactions with its environment.(no content)To learn to maximize rewards from these interactions, the agent makes decisions between trying new actions to learn more about the environment (exploration), or using current knowledge of the environment to take the best action (exploitation). The search for the optimal balance between these two strategies is known as the exploration–exploitation dilemma.

## Applications

Reinforcement learning has been applied successfully to various problems, including energy storage, robot control, photovoltaic generators, backgammon, checkers, Go (AlphaGo), and autonomous driving systems.(no content)Deep reinforcement learning has been used for a diverse set of applications including but not limited to robotics, video games, natural language processing, computer vision, education, transportation, finance and healthcare.

## Subfields and Techniques

Some specialized areas of reinforcement learning include:
- Multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) is a sub-field of reinforcement learning. It focuses on studying the behavior of multiple learning agents that coexist in a shared environment.
- Self-play is a technique for improving the performance of reinforcement learning agents.
- Reinforcement learning from human feedback (RLHF) is a technique to align an intelligent agent with human preferences.

I found comprehensive information about multi-agent systems collaboration. Here's what the search results show:

## Overview

A multi-agent system (MAS) is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.(no content)Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.

## Key Characteristics

Agents have autonomy and are at least partially independent and self-aware, with decentralization where no agent is designated as controlling.

## Communication and Collaboration

When agents can share knowledge using any agreed language within the constraints of the system's communication protocol, this can lead to common improvement, using languages such as Knowledge Query Manipulation Language (KQML) or Agent Communication Language (ACL).

## Types of Agent Interactions

Most real-world scenarios involving multiple agents have elements of both cooperation and competition, such as when multiple self-driving cars are planning their respective paths with diverging but not exclusive interests.

## Specialized Applications

Collaborative intelligence characterizes multi-agent, distributed systems where each agent, human or machine, is autonomously contributing to a problem solving network.(no content)Multi-agent planning involves coordinating the resources and activities of multiple agents, which can involve agents planning for a common goal, merging plans, or negotiating over tasks or resources.

The search results also show that multi-agent systems are increasingly being used in diverse applications including disaster response, defense, healthcare, and emerging AI-driven systems.

I've completed the web search on supply chain management disruption. Here's a summary of the key findings:

## Supply Chain Disruption Overview

Supply chain disruptions can affect a company's normal business and profitability, requiring modern management approaches like artificial intelligence to predict and analyze risks earlier so companies can respond faster.

## Historical Disruptions

One of the most significant recent events was the 2021-2023 global supply chain crisis caused by the COVID-19 pandemic and the Russian invasion of Ukraine. Economists pointed to lean manufacturing (also known as "just-in-time" manufacturing) as a major source of the supply chain disruption.

Supply chains disrupted during the COVID-19 pandemic faced huge challenges and struggled to recover, with manufacturers and distributors of goods stymied by worker shortages and a lack of key components and raw materials.

## Risk Factors

The complexity and globally outsourced nature of modern supply chains, combined with lean and just-in-time manufacturing practices, has increased supply chain vulnerabilities to even minor supply disruptions, exposing companies to risks from supplier bankruptcy, closing operations, data breaches, or acquisitions.

## Current Status

Despite some recovery after 2023, supply chains are still experiencing stress; by May 2025 the Global Supply Chain Pressure Index had risen to 0.19, reflecting renewed systemic bottlenecks.

I've completed a web search on "decision making artificial intelligence." Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Artificial intelligence (AI) is the capability of computational systems to perform tasks typically associated with human intelligence, such as learning, reasoning, problem-solving, perception, and decision-making.

## Automated Decision-Making

Automated decision-making (ADM) is the use of data, machines and algorithms to make decisions in a range of contexts, including public administration, business, health, education, law, employment, transport, media and entertainment, with varying degrees of human oversight or intervention.(no content)ADM technologies and applications can take many forms ranging from decision-support systems that make recommendations for human decision-makers to act on, sometimes known as augmented intelligence or 'shared decision-making', to fully automated decision-making processes that make decisions on behalf of individuals or organizations without human involvement.

## Expert Systems

An expert system is a computer system emulating the decision-making ability of a human expert, designed to solve complex problems by reasoning through bodies of knowledge, represented mainly as if–then rules rather than through conventional procedural programming code.

An intelligent decision support system (IDSS) is a decision support system that makes extensive use of artificial intelligence (AI) techniques.(no content)Ideally, an intelligent decision support system should behave like a human consultant: supporting decision makers by gathering and analysing evidence, identifying and diagnosing problems, proposing possible courses of action and evaluating such proposed actions.

Web search results for query: "algorithmic bias AI ethics"

Links: [{"title":"Algorithmic bias - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Algorithmic_bias"},{"title":"Ethics of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethics_of_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Regulation of artificial intelligence in the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regulation_of_artificial_intelligence_in_the_United_States"},{"title":"Machine ethics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_ethics"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence marketing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_marketing"},{"title":"Algorithmic accountability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Algorithmic_accountability"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pseudo_intelligence"},{"title":"Regulation of algorithms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regulation_of_algorithms"},{"title":"Generative artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generative_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"AI agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agentic_AI"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about algorithmic bias and AI ethics:

## What is Algorithmic Bias?

Algorithmic bias describes systematic and repeatable harmful tendency in a computerized sociotechnical system to create "unfair" outcomes, such as "privileging" one category over another in ways different from the intended function of the algorithm.(no content)Bias can emerge from many factors, including but not limited to the design of the algorithm or the unintended or unanticipated use or decisions relating to the way data is coded, collected, selected or used to train the algorithm.

## How Bias Enters AI Systems

The most predominant view on how bias is introduced into AI systems is that it is embedded within the historical data used to train the system. A concrete example is Amazon terminated their use of AI hiring and recruitment because the algorithm favored male candidates over female ones, because Amazon's system was trained with data collected over a 10-year period that included mostly male candidates.

## Real-World Examples

Notable instances of algorithmic bias include:
- Facial recognition algorithms made by Microsoft, IBM and Face++ all had biases when it came to detecting people's gender; these AI systems were able to detect the gender of white men more accurately than the gender of men of darker skin.
- Google Photos's new image labeling feature mistakenly identified Jacky Alcine and a friend as "gorillas" because they were black.

## AI Ethics Framework

The ethics of artificial intelligence covers a broad range of topics within AI that are considered to have particular ethical stakes, including algorithmic biases, fairness, accountability, transparency, privacy, and regulation, particularly where systems influence or automate human decision-making.

## Policy and Regulation

In 2023, New York City implemented a law requiring employers using automated hiring tools to conduct independent "bias audits" and publish the results, marking one of the first legally mandated transparency measures for AI systems used in employment decisions in the United States.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title, relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
